head_sha.description: The SHA of the commit that is being checked.

status.description: The phase of the lifecycle that the check is currently in.

conclusion.description: The final conclusion of the check. Can be one of `success`, `failure`, `neutral`, `cancelled`, `skipped`, `timed_out`, or `action_required`. When the conclusion is `action_required`, additional details should be provided on the site specified by `details_url`.

started_at.description: The time that the check run began. This is a timestamp in [ISO 8601](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601) format: `YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ`.

completed_at.description: The time the check completed. This is a timestamp in [ISO 8601](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601) format: `YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ`.

created_at.description: The time that the alert was created in ISO 8601 format: `YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ.`

html_url.description: The GitHub URL of the alert resource.

ref.description: The full Git reference, formatted as `refs/heads/<branch name>`.

analysis_key.description: Identifies the configuration under which the analysis was executed. For example, in GitHub Actions this includes the workflow filename and job name.

environment.description: Identifies the variable values associated with the environment in which the analysis that generated this alert instance was performed, such as the language that was analyzed.

state.description: State of a code scanning alert.
State of a code scanning alert.

dismissed_at.description: The time that the alert was dismissed in ISO 8601 format: `YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ`.

dismissed_reason.description: The reason for dismissing or closing the alert. Can be one of: `false positive`, `won't fix`, and `used in tests`.

id.description: A unique identifier for the rule used to detect the alert.

description.description: A short description of the rule used to detect the alert.

name.description: The name of the tool used to generate the code scanning analysis alert.

version.description: The version of the tool used to detect the alert.

app.description: GitHub apps are a new way to extend GitHub. They can be installed directly on organizations and user accounts and granted access to specific repositories. They come with granular permissions and built-in webhooks. GitHub apps are first class actors within GitHub.

name.description: The name of the GitHub app

permissions.description: The set of permissions for the GitHub app
